newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity closes up with Western outages.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity closes up with Western outages.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures closed higher Monday primarily on coal and nuclear power outages in the West, industry sources said.
"The Palo Verde (nuclear) unit is down, and I think that had a bit of a bullish effect," said one futures broker.
Arizona Public Service's 1,221 megawatt nuclear unit 1 in Wintersburg, Ariz. was taken off line over the weekend for refueling and maintenance that has been scheduled to last about 44 days.
Other coal units were reported to be off line in Washington and Montana, helping to boost spot electricity prices through the West on Monday.

October California Oregon Border (COB) futures settled up 37 cents at $15.84 after trade as low as $15.60, while November finished up 25 cents at $16.70 from trade as low as $16.55 per megawatt hour (MWh).
Remaining COB deferreds settled 10 cents higher.
October Palo Verde (PV) closed up 43 cents at $16.43 after trade as low as $16.05 per MWh, while November ended up 10 cents at $15.25 after trade in five cent range.
December was the only remaining PV month to trade, closing up five cents at $16.75 per MWh.
NYMEX said an estimated 286 COB and 53 PV contracts traded Monday.
-- Chris Reese, New York Power Desk 212-859-1627
